column4: if the filesystem is mounted, it may detect problems that don't actually exist, because the buffers haven't been flushed to disk, etc.
either force an fsck at boot, before the filesystem is mounted, or boot from a livecd and test from there.

from the e2fsck man page: it is safe if the -n option is specified, and -c, -l, or -L options are not specified. However, even if it is safe to do so, the results printed by e2fsck are not valid if the filesystem is mounted.
